Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Deciphering Subduction Dynamics: Case Study of the Catalina Schist
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subduction zones, which occur where two tectonic plates converge and one plate is thrust down into Earth's mantle, are the location of many important processes on Earth, including the generation of some of Earth's deadliest earthquakes and chains of volcanoes. At the interface between the subducting plate and the mantle significant heat transfer and physical and chemical exchange occur. To better understand how crustal and mantle materials move and interact within subduction zones, it is critically important to study rocks exhumed from this process. The proposed work will constrain how material moves within subduction zones by determining the temperature and pressure histories that these exhumed rocks experienced while in the subduction zone itself. For this work the principle investigators will analyze the chemical composition of the minerals rutile and titanite in rocks from a classic subduction locality, the Catalina Schist of southern California. They will then compare the recorded histories with histories predicted by different models for material behavior within subduction zones. In addition to the scientific goals of the project, this award is supporting the eduction of graduate and undergraduate students in an STEM discipline, is contributing to broadening of underrepresented groups in science, and the development of undergraduate course curricula in mineralogy and petrology. The project is facilitating a new collaboration between the partnering institutions involved in this effort, and is contributing direct exchange of scientific methods and analytical standards between trace element/geochronology laboratories. The results that derive from this project are being disseminated to the scientific community through research publications and presentations, and the data are being archived in appropriate community databases.

This project will exploit new developments in thermobarometry and geochronology to better understand subduction zone tectonics, using exposures of Catalina Schist on Santa Catalina Island, California, as a type example. The work will provide new, high-precision Pressure-Temperature-time (P-T-t) constraints that critically test tectonic models with unprecedented geographic scope and precision. The proposed research addresses broad geodynamic questions, e.g. to what degree does flow in the subduction channel change temporally and affect subduction thermal evolution? In addition, the principle investigators will continue to develop petrologic and chronologic tools that broadly advance petrogenetic research in other fields. This research will address two main issues in the tectonic evolution of subduction zones: (1) What is the scale of melange flow as melange matrix progressively metamorphoses? (2) What tectonic processes produced distinctive high-Temperature subduction-related rocks? Numerous different models have been generally proposed. Four basic sets of data will be collected: (1) Samples will be collected over a well-mapped area of melange and along three key transects. (2) Electron microprobe analysis will provide Pressure-Time estimates and identify specific titanite and rutile grains and domains for trace element analysis. (3) Laser-ablation Inductively-coupled-mass spectrometry (LA-ICPMS) on a sub-grain scale (50-100 micron spots) will constrain temperature and time, respectively. (4) Raman spectroscopy of mineral inclusions will constrain entrapment pressures on the prograde Pressure-Temperature path. The resulting data will be used to test tectonic models by characterizing the degree of Pressure-Temperature-time homogeneity (scale of mixing) within a melange zone and Pressure-Temperature-time trends across structure. All data will be permanently archived with MetPetDB.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to investigate the evolution of subduction zone rocks on Santa Catalina Island, California, using the geochemistry and geochronology of metamorphic rocks. Several different models have been proposed for their evolution, with predictions that differ according to pressure-temperature conditions and ages. Our work mainly involved collecting and interpreting chemical compositions of metamorphic minerals to infer pressures and temperatures of formation. One major distinctive dichotomy in testing models is the distribution temperatures through the melange sequence, which affects our understanding of physical mixing processes during subduction.

Our primary result shows small but measurable temperature differences among melange zone rocks, despite major differences in rock types. This indicates that chaotic mixing occurred on large length scales (100s of meters to kilometers) prior to the peak of metamorphism. But further mixing after the peak of metamorphism was markedly reduced. This behavior makes mineralogical sense as weak phyllosilicates, typical of low metamorphic grades, should promote large-scale mixing, whereas high-grade amphiboles should stiffen the melange matrix and reduce scales of mixing. This work has been presented at numerous conferences and lectures, and we are in the process of writing up the results.

A second major result looked at pressure-temperature conditions recorded by subduction zone rocks in comparison with thermal-mechanical models of subduction. This work showed that typical subduction models underestimate metamorphic temperatures by 200 °C at depths shallower than ~70 km. These results indicate either that the physical record of subduction is highly biased, or that thermal models typically overlook important heat contributions, for example from shearing or metamorphic reactions.

Every project has ancillary research endeavors and outcomes, mainly directed towards understanding what controls our signals. In this study we encountered an unexpected and unrecognized problem relating to the use of diffusion profiles in accessory mineral for inferring high-temperature cooling rates. Previous studies have assumed that near-rim diffusion profiles can be inverted to solve for cooling rates. Our discovery of disparate diffusion profiles in rutile grains separated from a single rock imply that reequilibration of trace elements is strongly influenced by transport processes within the matrix. That is, in some textural settings, trace elements can enter or exit a specific mineral grain with ease, whereas in other textural settins, trace elements are severely restricted in their ability to reequilibrate. This result not only implies that retrieval of cooling rates is vastly more complicated than previously suspected, but also helps explain otherwise enigmatic variations in trace element temperatures recorded by different rutile grains in a rock.

We also determined that unusually high temperatures determined for the mineral titanite probably do not reflect "real" temperatures, but rather kinetic artifacts related to the breakdown of Zr-rich rutile to form Zr-poor titanite. Essentially, the Zr from rutile is unable to fully escape the reaction zone, leading to (relatively) Zr-enriched titanite, and erroneously high apparent temperatures.

Last, we are continuing to develop a new technique involving the use of Raman spectroscopy on mineral inclusions to determine conditions of mineral growth and inclusion entrapment. This technique is now proven (mainly) for quartz inclusions in garnet to constrain pressures, and we are processing Raman spectroscopic data to determine prograde metamorphic pressures during subduction.

This grant directly supported the focused research and educational activities of  1 undergraduate student emphasizing trace elements in metamorphic rocks, and 1 graduate student at the University of Maryland. Rocks from this study were also used in two classroom projects at Boise State University, teaching mineralogy and petrology, with outreach to approximately 50 undergraduate geology majors. Research results have been publicized through numerous public and institutional outreach activities, both in the US and abroad. The PIs presented their research project to staff at the Catalina Island Conservancy, which interfaces between scientists and the public.
